name: ex
content:
ex

noun
 
/eks/
 
/eks/
(plural exes)
(informal)
jump to other results
  1. a person’s former wife, husband or partner
    • The children are spending the weekend with my ex and his new wife.
    Topics Family and relationshipsc1
    Word Originnoun early 19th cent.: independent usage of ex-.
See ex in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ex

name: ex
content:
ex

preposition
 
/eks/
 
/eks/
(British English)
jump to other results
  1. not including something
    • The price is £1 500 ex VAT.
    Word Originpreposition mid 19th cent.: from Latin, ‘out of’.
Check pronunciation: ex

name: ex-
content:
ex-

/eks/
 
/eks/

name: Tipp-Ex™
content:
Tipp-Ex™

noun
 
/ˈtɪp eks/
 
/ˈtɪp eks/
[uncountable] (British English)
jump to other results
  1. a liquid, usually white, that you use to cover mistakes that you make when you are writing or typing, and that you can write on top of; a type of correction fluid
Check pronunciation: Tipp-Ex™

name: ex gratia
content:
ex gratia

adverb
 
/ˌeks ˈɡreɪʃə/
 
/ˌeks ˈɡreɪʃə/
(from Latin)
jump to other results
  1. as a gift or favour, not because there is a legal duty to do it
    • The sum was paid ex gratia.
Check pronunciation: ex gratia

name: ex gratia
content:
ex gratia

adjective
 
/ˌeks ˈɡreɪʃə/
 
/ˌeks ˈɡreɪʃə/
(from Latin)
jump to other results
  1. given or done as a gift or favour, not because there is a legal duty to do it
    • ex gratia payments
    Word OriginLatin, literally ‘from favour’, from ex ‘from’ and gratia, from gratus ‘pleasing, thankful’.
See ex gratia in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ex gratia

name: ex libris
content:
ex libris

adverb
 
/ˌeks ˈlɪbrɪs/,
 
/ˌeks ˈliːbrɪs/
 
/ˌeks ˈlɪbrɪs/,
 
/ˌeks ˈliːbrɪs/
(from Latin)
jump to other results
  1. written in the front of a book before the name of the person the book belongs to
    • ex libris David Harries
See ex libris in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ex libris

name: ex cathedra
content:
ex cathedra

adverb, adjective
 
/ˌeks kəˈθiːdrə/
 
/ˌeks kəˈθiːdrə/
(formal, religion)
jump to other results
  1. speaking or said with the authority of your position
    • The Pope was speaking ex cathedra.
    • This papal judgement is not ex cathedra.
    Word OriginLatin, ‘from the (teacher's) chair’, from ex ‘from’ and cathedra ‘seat’ (from Greek kathedra).
See ex cathedra in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: ex cathedra

name: ex officio
content:
ex officio

adverb
 
/ˌeks əˈfɪʃiəʊ/
 
/ˌeks əˈfɪʃiəʊ/
(from Latin, formal)
jump to other results
  1. because of your job, rank or position
    • He was present at the meeting ex officio.
Check pronunciation: ex officio

name: ex officio
content:
ex officio

adjective
 
/ˌeks əˈfɪʃiəʊ/
 
/ˌeks əˈfɪʃiəʊ/
(from Latin, formal)
jump to other results
  1. included or allowed because of your job, position or rank
    • an ex officio member of the committee
    Word OriginLatin, from ex ‘out of, from’ + officium ‘duty’.
See ex officio in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: ex-directory
content:
ex-directory

adjective
 
/ˌeks dəˈrektəri/,
 
/ˌeks daɪˈrektəri/
 
/ˌeks dəˈrektəri/,
 
/ˌeks daɪˈrektəri/
 (British English)
jump to other results
  1. (of a person or phone number) not listed in the public phone book and not available through directory enquiries, at the request of the owner of the phone
    • an ex-directory number
    • She's ex-directory.
    see also unlistedTopics Phones, email and the internetc2
Check pronunciation: ex-directory

name: deus ex machina
content:
deus ex machina

noun
 
/ˌdeɪʊs eks ˈmækɪnə/
 
/ˌdeɪʊs eks ˈmækɪnə/
[singular] (literary)
jump to other results
  1. an unexpected power or event that saves a situation that seems without hope, especially in a play or novel
    Word Originlate 17th cent.: modern Latin, translation of Greek theos ek mēkhanēs, ‘god from the machinery’. In Greek theatre, actors representing gods were suspended above the stage, the denouement of the play being brought about by their intervention.
See deus ex machina in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: deus ex machina
